text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

BRIAN KENNY: According to
the National Confectioners

Association, 80% of Americans
who are giving gifts

to their sweetheart
on Valentine's Day

plan to share
chocolate and candy.

And if there was any doubt about
whether that's a good choice,

94% agree that's exactly
the gift they want most.

And for those who don't
have a sweetheart,

43% plan to buy a box of
chocolate for themselves.

All those sweets will add
up to about $1.7 billion
in sales in the US alone.

The tradition of expressing
one's love on February 14
dates back centuries.

But the romance between
chocolate and Valentine's Day

appears to have begun
in England in 1868,

when Cadbury introduced
a gift box of chocolates

in the shape of a heart, and
a new tradition was born.

Today we'll hear from
Professor Nancy Koehn

about her case
entitled "Candy Land:

The Utopian Vision
of Milton Hershey".

I'm your host Brian Kenny, and
you're listening to Cold Call.

SPEAKER 1: So we are all
sitting there in the classroom.
SPEAKER 2: Professor walks in.

SPEAKER 3: And they look up,
and you know what's coming.

SPEAKER 4: Oh, the
dreaded cold call.

BRIAN KENNY: Nancy Koehn
is a business historian

whose research focuses
on effective leadership,

and how leaders past and present
craft lives of purpose, worth,
and impact.

Her most recent book,
Forged in Crisis The Power

of Courageous Leadership
in Turbulent Times,

spotlights how five of history's
greatest leaders managed crises

and what we can learn from
each of their experiences.

And Milton Hershey
didn't even make the cut.

So it'll be interesting
because he's

had a pretty
impressive life, Nancy.
NANCY KOEHN: He certainly has.

BRIAN KENNY: Thanks
for joining me today.

NANCY KOEHN: It's my
sincere pleasure, Brian.

BRIAN KENNY: What inspired
you to write this case?

NANCY KOEHN: You know,
that's a great question.

I had read a little bit
about his bankruptcies.
So I love Hershey's chocolate.

By mother loved Hershey's
almond chocolate bars,
and I grew up with them.

And you know, everyone
knows the Hershey Kiss.

And I, unlike many more
sophisticated chocolate lovers,

didn't mind the slightly waxy
element of the Hershey's milk
chocolate bar.

So I learned that he had gone
bankrupt a number of times.

And you know, we don't write
about failures a great deal
at the Harvard Business School.

Historians don't
write about failures

because people who
fail and organizations

that don't succeed
actually don't really

want to tell their story,
more often than not.

So I started digging
into the failures.

And the more I learned,
the more fascinated

I became by him and
what he created.
He was a candy maker at heart.
He was an entrepreneur.
He was a restless spirit.
He was an experimenter.

He loved nothing more
than sleeves rolled up,
jumping into the lab--

or it really wasn't a lab
in the early 20th century--

jumping onto the factory
floor and throwing

Rice Krispies, for example,
into a pot of chocolate,
and creating the Crackle bar.
BRIAN KENNY: Crackle, yeah.

NANCY KOEHN: He was he
was always, if you will,

mixing and matching
and experimenting.

And so the more I learned
about him and the things he was

making--because
it was all candy.

Most of his life is about
candy, and I love candy--
the more interested I became.

And I just, said we've
got to write this up.

And once you get to a man
creating a town, the utopian

vision of Milton Hershey, it's
good enough to be a movie.

And so I'm a
storyteller at heart,

and so I just couldn't
resist the story.

BRIAN KENNY: And we'll
talk more about that town

because that's a really unique
aspect of his life story.
What was his childhood like?

NANCY KOEHN: His
childhood is very
interesting and tumultuous.

He was born to Mennonite
parents in 1857 in Pennsylvania,

not far from
Lancaster in a county
called Derry, Pennsylvania.

His father was another
restless spirit

who everything that he
touched turned to mud.

So he had seven or
eight different kinds

of careers, everything
from opening a bookstore

to making cough drops to trying
his hand at oil refining.

And he basically went
belly up in each instance.

And his wife-- Fanny
Snavely was her maiden name.
His name was Henry Hershey--

she got tired of all
this after a while

and eventually just moved
quietly away from him

because in the Mennonite
church, you didn't divorce.
She settled in Lancaster.

Milton stayed with
his mother, but Henry

kept kind of rolling
in with the latest

get rich quick scheme, which
ultimately went nowhere.

And when his son got old
enough to be an adult,

he dragged his son through
a bunch of failed ventures.
So it was tumultuous.

And we can see the
effects of this on Milton

because at one point
early in his life--

he can't me much older
than five or six--

they're in Southern
Central Pennsylvania,

and Lee is marching
up towards Gettysburg.

And he gets very nervous
that his family's
going to be attacked.

And so he gathers all
his pennies, $0.17,

and he buries them
in the ground.

So here's a young person
that already has had
lots of commotion in his life.

And he's saying, I'm going
to put a little stake
in the ground.

Here are my pennies
in the coffee can.

So I think his childhood
was difficult for him.

Early on his mother apprenticed
him out to a printer.
That did not work.
So he was, I think, 11 or 12.

And then she quickly finds
him a job at a candy maker
outside of Lancaster.
And there's the beginning.
And he never looks back.

So the childhood was
interesting, full

of lots of change, but then
ultimately gets anchored,

I think, in lots of
different ways, in candy.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

And it sounds like
pretty unsettled for him,

too, and maybe some
insecurities there,

and a feeling that
he needed to protect
the family and his mother.
NANCY KOEHN: Very much so.

He had a sister who died when
she was relatively young.

That was really, I think, the
ostensible reason that Fanny

finally said enough with
her ne'er-do-well husband.

But he, I think,
had a great sense

of I need to prove myself,
and I need to prove myself
for my mother particularly.
He was very close to his mother.

She never left him, even
after he married later.

Fanny Snavely could
be seen it well

into her 60s wrapping
Kisses on the factory floor,

wrapping them in foil
with the little flag.

BRIAN KENNY: And they
did that by hand.

NANCY KOEHN: And
they did it by hand

for years and years
and years, yeah.

BRIAN KENNY: Now you
mentioned General Lee.

What was the backdrop in the
United States at the time?

So he's coming of age
in the late 1800s.
What was going on around him?
NANCY KOEHN: He's born in 1857.

By the time the Civil War
ends, he's eight years old.

And then the American
economy-- we all

have a vague sense of
this-- really takes off.

The Transcontinental Railroad
is complete at the end
of the 18060s.

What Alfred Chandler, the
great business historian

would call the Second
Industrial Revolution

arrives in terms of the coming
of managerial capitalism,

the rise of large businesses,
first railroads, steel,

eventually automobiles,
mass retailing,

cigarette manufacturer,
food manufacturer.

Henry Heinz will get
his start here along

with some of the great meat
packers like Swift and Armor.

It is a moment of great
economic and social advancement

and corresponding increases
in income inequality.
But overall, a grand--

kind of if we would use
this modern language--

GDP level that was not the
language Milton Hershey

or any of the
American presidents

would have used in
the late 19th century.

But at that level, American
incomes are rising.

So being able to afford
something like candy,

and eventually chocolate, which
was largely nonexistent until

the 1870s in America-- not very
popular at all until the turn
of the century--

was now becoming something that
more and more Americans could
do.
They could afford candy.

BRIAN KENNY: What was
the state of the candy
industry at the time?

NANCY KOEHN: So the state
of the candy industry

is just imagine little
house on the prairie,

or a little house
in the big woods.

And Pa goes to
the general store.
It was lemon drops.
It was like candied ginger.

It was peppermint
and candy canes.

It was some what today we would
call pralines, but small, like,
maple sugar candies.

But we had nothing like
M&M's, nothing like Twizzlers,
nothing like malted milk balls.
Nothing like gummy bears.

It looked nothing like,
in variety or the spectrum

of possible tastes, the
candy aisle in any store,

or the space underneath the
register at any counter.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

There's a recurring
reference to cough drops
throughout the case.

Cough drops seem to
have been very popular.
NANCY KOEHN: Very popular.

They were, like
today, partly a candy.

Milton's father,
Henry, and Milton

get into a couple of different
cough drop-making and -selling

enterprises or ventures,
which don't work.
But cough drops were popular.

But again, like
the other candies

that we just talked about,
these were sold in small stores,
largely in bulk.

So you didn't say, I'll
have a roll of Lifesavers
or a bar of sugared maple.

You had a barrel,
and the shopkeeper

scooped up a little
bit of lemon drops

and put them in a
paper bag for you.

The way we can think about
this relative to our times--

and it ties back to
your introduction,

Brian-- is in about 1870,
the average American

consumed 25 pounds
of sugar a year.
So that's everything.
That's mom's apple pies.
That's muffins.

That's wherever you
could sprinkle over
your fruit in the summer.

And today the average
American consumes

close to 150 pounds of
sugar, so six times as much.

So we just didn't have
the supply of sugar,

and we didn't have
many other kinds

of inputs like effective,
efficient, tasty,

and non-perishable ways
of making chocolate

because chocolate
is, by far and away,

still today, America's
favorite candy ingredient.

And it just didn't
exist in anything
like its form or quantity then.

BRIAN KENNY: But in these
early entrepreneurial attempts

that Milton made, chocolate
was nowhere in the picture.
And he did fail.

Can you talk a little bit
about what he set out to do,

and maybe what he
learned from it?

NANCY KOEHN: By
the time he's 30,

he's failed in two different
kinds of candy businesses.

He's not yet making
chocolate, and he's not yet

making caramel, which will
be the runway, interestingly
enough, to chocolate for him.

He learned, I think,
about a couple of things.

And they're lessons that
lots of entrepreneurs,

from Josiah Wedgwood
to Steve Jobs--

and that is how to grow
viably without growing

so fast that you run out of
cash and kind of hit the wall.
It's a very classic problem.
In Fin 1, there's Butler Lumber.
There's Wilson Lumber.

There's all kinds of cases
that the students here study.

BRIAN KENNY: Fin 1 being
one of our MBA courses here.
NANCY KOEHN: Right.

Study about this very
basic thing, which is you
want to grow, you want to grow.

But you can't initially
collect the money

you need to collect
fast enough to pay what
you owe in terms of inputs.

And so he learns that because
that's one of the things
that he gets into trouble with.

So he learns how to
grow at a viable pace.

I think the second
thing he learns,

and this is really important,
is he learns not to get out too

far ahead-- he wouldn't
have said this, obviously,
if you will, ski tips--
in terms of what consumers want.

Both bankruptcies, I think,
help him develop something

that I studied a great
deal in my first decade

at the Harvard
Business School, which

is how do entrepreneurs
anticipate what consumers

may want before they know
that they want something?

So how did Howard Schultz
say, you can't start
your day without a flat white?

Well, no one in America had
ever heard of a flat white.

Or how did Henry
Heinz say, you're

going to put ketchup, bottled
ketchup, on every piece of meat

you eat, when most Americans
had never heard of ketchup?
I'm fascinated by demand side.
That's innovative.

That's creative
imagination, and then
innovation on the demand side.

Both of Milton
Hershey's bankruptcies
help him develop that.

And that's going to turn out--
to something you said just
a minute ago, Brian--

to be very important
in how he, more

than any other single
individual, breaks

open the American
market for chocolate.

BRIAN KENNY: What's the
turning point for him?

He's got these two
failures under his belt.
He's got no money.

Nobody wants to
give him that stuff.
NANCY KOEHN: No.

And it's a wing and a prayer,
and it's some relatives' money.

But the real kicker
is a businessman that

comes through Lancaster,
an English businessman,

and tastes his caramels and
said, you need to expand.
These are so good.

In the, really, mid-1880s,
a little bit earlier,
he gets into caramels.

He's fiddling and diddling
because it's all about the milk

not going sour, and the
caramel being the right texture
and being tasty.

And he found something called
the Lancaster Caramel Factory.

And so these angels swoop
in-- like lots and lots

of great startup companies
that become silverback gorillas

in the land of business--
and help him along

because they like
the product, and they
believe in his determination.
This guy is so determined.

He just won't take
no for an answer.

He's doing very well in the
Lancaster Caramel Factory,

and then he gets
interested in chocolate.

And he gets interested
in chocolate

because he happens to be, in
1893, in Chicago at the Grand

Columbian World Exposition, a
world fair, very, very famous

world fair there, and he sees
a chocolate manufacturing
exhibit.
And that gets him interested.

Comes back and starts
playing with chocolate.

But it still takes him a
good seven or eight years

before he really has tinkered
his way into a chocolate

texture, a means
of manufacturing

because what's a chocolate
bar supposed to look like?

You don't know that before
you have mass chocolate bars,

mass marketed chocolate bars,
so a way of putting it together.

So it takes him a good
seven or eight years

before he's really ready to
say, I'm done with caramels.

I'm going whole
hog for chocolate.

And that really begins to
happen in the very late 1890s.

He sells the Lancaster Caramel
Company for $1 million,

takes that money, and
pours it into chocolate,

and into milk chocolate because
another interesting historical
fact.

What chocolate there was
around, going all the way back

to the Baker Brothers-- many
of your listeners who are cooks

will know Baker Chocolate--
that goes all the way back
to the late 1700s.

The Baker Brothers were
using dark chocolate.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

That's not the kind of
chocolate you would snack on.
NANCY KOEHN: No.
No, no, no.

And its health
benefits are not known.

It's not like it is today
at all, dark chocolate.
It's mostly bitter.

And people use it with
sugar to make hot chocolate
for their kids.
So it's a very different market.

But Hershey is convinced that
milk chocolate-- and he's piggy

backing on people
like Nestle who,

in Switzerland at
this time, is really

beginning to produce
milk chocolate that

tastes delicious and can
be sold and won't go bad.

And so he really
is riding a wave

that's not so obvious
in Pennsylvania,

but that's happening
in other parts.

And his stake in the ground is
milk chocolate, affordable milk
chocolate.

He makes another really
important decision,

which is I'm not going
to be a luxury good.

BRIAN KENNY: Which was
different, because at the time,

chocolate was considered
a luxury good.
NANCY KOEHN: Largely a luxury.

So even Cadbury, which
eventually becomes

a really successful
mass market company,

they started out selling
primarily to wealthy Britons.

BRIAN KENNY: This was the
point in the case where

I started to really see him
as a visionary, somebody

who was innovating in
really interesting ways.

And I thought it began just
with the physical plant

and the way he set up
the manufacturing plant.

Can you talk about
that a little bit?
NANCY KOEHN: Sure.

A lot of entrepreneurial
success is

based on placing
these unusual bets

with a lot of
people telling you,
it's never been done before.
You can't do that.

And the entrepreneurs
say, I think we can.

Another one of those decisions--
besides we're going to mass

market it, and we're
going to do milk,

and we're going to figure out
how to make this taste really
good--

another one of those decisions,
I'm going to build a town.

I'm going to build
a factory in a town,

and I'm going to
locate it in a place

where I don't really
have a lot of transport.

It's not like you're in New
York or Philadelphia or Boston.

It's not clear
initially how we're

going to easily reach
lots of markets.

But the draw for Pennsylvania
was twofold, I guess threefold.
One, close to his family.
That was important.

He will quickly hire lots
and lots of Hersheys.

This will be very much a
family company, like Heinz,

like Wedgwood,
like Estee Lauder,

like lots of companies that
start off in someone's kitchen,

and the family becomes the first
set of partners and employees
and flag bearers.

The first reason,
my family's there.

Second reason, there's
really good dairy cows.
I need a lot of milk.

Thirdly, there's
really good fresh water

because you need a ton of
water to make chocolate.

You need water at almost
every step of the way

to wash the cocoa beans,
to mix in with all kinds

of ingredients, and to
just run through some
of the products in the factory.

So he's going to set up his own
vertically integrated factory,
and then surrounding town.

And this vision really
gets built out in his head,

and then in reality, in material
form, between about 1900

and about 1908, with a lot of
it done in the first years.

And the factory is set
up so that it really
can be mass produced.

Again, none of this
has ever been done.

So we're going to bring
the cocoa beans in here.
We're going to roast them.
Literally the stuff travels.

Now initially it's by
cart and it's messy.

But eventually it will
travel by conveyor belt.

The cocoa beans will travel
into the pounding factory.

They have be ground
to just finest powder.

It's incredibly dirty,
incredibly complicated,
incredibly loud.

Lots and lots of workers lost
a lot of hearing in that room.

And then that powder
has to then get

mixed with a whole
bunch of stuff

very carefully in a very,
very specific order.

Rivers of chocolate
will travel to where

they need to get to be poured
into these trays, all of which
say Hershey in bar form.
And then they will be cooled.

That has to be exactly
the right temperature.

And then they'll be flipped
over, initially manually, later

by machines, and then wrapped
by hand and then packed.

The whole factory is set up in
a very, very innovative, very

logical way, as opposed to this
is a little lemon drop company
outside of Philadelphia.

We make the lemon drops
on a bunch of tables,

and it's a small batch operation
with about 10 people making
lemon drops.

This is set up from the get
go, even though he doesn't yet

have the market, to be a
factory in which he can produce

thousands and thousands and
thousands of bars a day,

and in which he can expand
and incorporate the latest
technology.

So the main factory in
Hershey, Pennsylvania-- any

of your listeners
have been there,

they know how much
the town still

smells like chocolate-- the
main factory for Hershey Candy

Company is still the
factory he built. There's

lots of other places
they make chocolate,

but it speaks to
the farsightedness

of what he saw that
that plant is still

at the center of a
lot of manufacturing

operations for this
gigantic candy company.

BRIAN KENNY: Let's talk a
little bit more about the town

because this notion
of the company town,

I didn't realize until
reading the case,

this was a pretty prominent
movement back in that time.

And it was done
well in some places
and done not well in others.

I always think about
Pottersville, the dystopian

future that the
character in It's

A Wonderful Life sees
when he's looking
at the counterfactual life.

What was Hersheytown
like in Hershey's eyes?

NANCY KOEHN: He wanted
it to be a place where

all of his workers
could feel like they

had everything they needed for
their work and their family
life.

It was a town that he
built very purposely.

Obviously, he had some
construction interest

because he had a
hand in everything.

It was a town in which he
built not only the basic

infrastructure--a bank,
schools, a library, stores--

and built housing,
these individual houses.

He didn't want them
all to look exactly

alike like they did in George
Pullman, the railroad car

magnate's town
outside of Chicago.

They were on streets
like Cocoa Avenue.

And each of the street light
shades are Hershey's Kisses.

It's all very much
Hershey'd, if you will.

But not only is there
housing and all the services.
There's a pool.
There's a dance hall.

There will be the beginnings
of an amusement park.

But he wanted a
town in which people

could spend their
whole lives and feel

like they lived in a wonderful
place, an egalitarian place.

So when I say utopian vision
in the title of the case,
that's what I'm talking about.

That was his driving
train of ideas here.

BRIAN KENNY: But there
was some, shall we say,
dissension along the way.

He did have to deal with
some workers' issues.
There was no OSHA back then.

But this was the days
where unions were forming,

and there was some activity
they had to deal with.
Can you describe that?
NANCY KOEHN: Sure.

When you own the business,
the working conditions

never appear the same as
when you work for the man
or woman who owns the business.

We're never going to make
those exactly the same picture.

And I think all along, people
that worked for Hershey
had some qualms about it.

Not that he had any
shortage of people

who wanted to come to
Hershey, Pennsylvania.

Plenty of people
wanted to get there
and be there and stay there.

But they worried about whether
he was watching over them a lot

because he was always wandering
through his bank or his library
or his theater.

In the 1930s, with
unemployment--

well, by 1935, it's down from
its high of about 26% or 27%

in the midst of the
Great Depression--
but it's still plenty high.
It's 20% or over.

And real gains in union
membership and union clout

start to unfold and
really, really multiply.

The CIO organizers
come to Hershey's plant

just after the sit down strike
at GM and try to organize.
And eventually they do.

They eventually, with a lot of
division in the work force--

some of the workforce wants to
stay on the job just the way
they are.

Some of the workforce
wants to unionize.

This pains Milton
Hershey to no end.

I mean, it just
tears at his heart

that the people that
he's, in a sense, created

this town and that he believes,
true or not, that he's

serving so well, he
feels have turned on him.

In the end, the CIO is
recognized as the bargaining
representative for workers.

And the story of labor strife
at Hershey largely dies down.

But Milton Hershey will die
eight years later in 1945.

And he never recovered
completely emotionally
from what he felt was--

betrayal may be a little strong,
but a very, very surprising

turnabout on the part
of some of his workers

toward all that he thought
he had done for them.

BRIAN KENNY: He was
a very caring guy

because the case
talks about the fact

that he was really concerned
about people struggling

during the
Depression, and wanted

to make sure that, right
down to the individual,
that so-and-so was OK.

NANCY KOEHN: The workers
whether the depression

in Hershey, Pennsylvania much
better than most workers did.

Now let's remember-- let's
go back to his childhood.

This is someone who never
knew the stability of a house

and a library and a
pool, and eventually

a railroad that'll take him
to and from other parts.

Maybe part of what
he was doing--

I won't put him on the couch
for too long-- was building

the infrastructure that he
never knew as a young man,
as a child and a young man.

And you could grow up
in Hershey, Pennsylvania

and never have any
sense of all the turmoil
that he experienced.

So I think we want to just
put that little dollop, if you
will, on our piece of chocolate.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

And is that, maybe, not
what drives him to establish
the orphanage that he does?

NANCY KOEHN: To me,
that, in some ways,

is the most interesting
part of this story

because of its extraordinary
footprint today.
So he marries at the age of 41.

He marries a woman about
17 years younger than he,
a woman named Kitty.

And he meets her
when he's traveling
on one of his sales trips.

And they fall quickly in love,
and they try to have children
and cannot.

Fast forward a
couple of decades.

Before she's 50,
becomes very ill.

And after she dies, he is
just absolutely wrecked.

I think a huge piece
of his offering to her
was to endow an orphanage.

And so he builds the Hershey
Industrial School for Boys

and plays a very active role in
it all the way up to his death.

Now here's the thing that, to
me, is just so fascinating.

When he dies, he has
given away, basically,

all his money and a huge amount
of his stock in the Hershey

Chocolate Company,
which went public

in the early 20th century after
the First World War ended.

That stock became so
valuable that today, in 2019,

on a per student basis, it's the
wealthiest school in the world.
BRIAN KENNY: Wow.

NANCY KOEHN: It's certainly
holding its own with Harvard

in terms of just huge endowments
because the stock appreciate
so much.
It's a great school.
And he could see this.
Maybe he can.

You just know he's
chortling in joy with it.
BRIAN KENNY: That's great.

There's so much
more to this case.

We're not going to get
to it all the day, Nancy.
It's a really rich case.

But one thing I wanted
to ask is, is it

possible to have
this kind of story
